(Same as ANCMED 101 1 and JS 180 1)
(Topic: People and Their Gods)
(This course satisfies the Religion major requirement:- Region.)
(This course provides a survey introduction to the study of the distinctive and interrelated cultures of the ancient Mediterranean world, from the Bronze Age until the Christianization of the Roman Empire (ca. 3300 BCE to ca. 400 CE). Subtitled "People and Their Gods," the course gives special attention to cultural phenomena identified with the category of "religion." Drawing on a range of evidence, both material and literary, we will explore how ancient Mediterranean people understood and interpreted stories about gods and other powerful beings ("myths"); polytheism and monotheism; veneration of images ("idolatry"); tradition and innovation in religious beliefs and practices; the significance of sacrifice (including human sacrifice); how Jews and Christians viewed so-called "pagans" and how "pagans" viewed Jews and Christians; the ancient Mediterranean roots and sources of present-day religious traditions.)
course_description: Social, anthropological, and cultural aspects of two or more ancient Mediterranean cultures from a comparative perspective.
